mods:mods.mods:abstract: John, Jay presumes that Washington will be at Philadelphia, and that if he is not, a member of his family will forward the letter to him. When John Jay was asked whether any arrangements had been made concerning the regulation of trade with the Indian tribes, he replied that he presumed that necessary measures would soon be enacted. John Jay recommends the enactment of uniform laws concerning the regulation of United States currency and the punishment of counterfeiting. Care should also be taken concerning the roads Congress is empowered to establish. It may be advisable to establish a fortress near Fort "Pit" in order "to secure communication between the western and Atlantic countries." One such fortress should be established in the north and another in the south soon, for "Peace is the Time to prepare for Defence against Hostilities." There is reason to think that timber may become scarce, and measures should be taken to prevent waste. It might also be a good idea to think of measures the national government might take to prevent frauds in exports, and to ensure the quality of exported provisions. Where state inspection laws are good, they might be adopted, but if various states are inspect by different rules, the possibility of frauds are multiplied. The New Englanders appear to think well of recent acts of Congress, particularly of the regulations preventing control by private interest. John Jay asked the judges for their opinions of the judicial act in August, but he has not yet heard from them. Draft. 2 p.
